awd_titl_txt: MRI: Acquisition of a Fluorescence Microscopy System for Research and Teaching at Kettering University
awd_abstract_narration:
This award is to purchase an advanced fluorescence microscopy system for Kettering University. The system will enable high-resolution, three-dimensional imaging of cells on a microscopic scale. These capabilities allow molecules and nanoparticles that have potential for enhancing disease treatments to be tracked relative to various parts of the cell. The system will support interdisciplinary research in studying cellular processes with the goal of improving treatment of cancer and other diseases. The system will provide excellent training opportunities for students to prepare them for graduate school or employment in scientific fields after graduation. The system will also enable science-oriented outreach to women and other underrepresented minorities via pre-college programs and summer research experiences for undergraduates. Furthermore, the instrument will be used to provide professional development for teachers and enhance science education of under-served students in Flint and surrounding areas via field trips to the university and Internet-enabled remote microscopy demonstrations.

This instrument will include an inverted microscope with epifluorescence components and light source, an electron-multiplier CCD camera, and a confocal laser scanning system, all of which are critical for the study of the localization and transport of molecules and nanoparticles. The first project will study the mechanisms of ultrasound-mediated delivery of fluorescent agents to cells in the presence of microbubbles, thereby potentially enabling better non-invasive spatiotemporal control of drug delivery. The second project will study the symmetry-breaking mechanisms of eukaryotic cells during movement with fluorescent dyes, thereby contributing to an improved understanding of metastasis. The third project will study the uptake and distribution of fluorescent magnetic nanoparticles in cancerous cells and spheroids with magnetic and ultrasonic methods. These magnetic nanoparticles can be used for noninvasive hyperthermic cancer treatment via induction heating. The fourth project will study the biotoxicity of fluorescent silver nanoparticles on yeast as a model for treating infectious fungi. The fifth project will test fluorescent gold nanoclusters as a means to image beta-amyloid aggregates and study the process of beta-amyloid plaque formation towards a better understanding of Alzheimer's disease. The final project will develop fluorescent quantum dots and characterize their ability to act as nanothermometers in the intra- and extracellular environment during hyperthermia.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

PROJECT OUTCOMES REPORT FOR THE GENERAL PUBLIC

Overview: We have acquired and installed a fluorescence microscopy system at Kettering University, a primarily undergraduate institution focused on science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM) that emphasizes experiential learning. The system has been incorporated as part of suite of instrumentation for teaching, training, and research. The major system components include an inverted microscope with epifluorescence components and light source, a high-sensitivity electron-multiplier charged-coupled device (emCCD) camera, and a confocal laser scanning system (Fig. 1). Other components include a stage-top environmental control system for temperature control and an objective lens inverter extension. A laboratory space on campus was renovated to create a Laboratory for Advanced Microscopy in the main academic building on campus.  Finally we have deployed a web site (https://sites.google.com/kettering.edu/klam), access form, and calendar to promote use of the instrument.

Intellectual Merit: The system has supported a variety supported interdisciplinary scientific research efforts themed around physics and biology:

  • Three-dimensional imaging of plant cells (Lithospermum) in collaboration with a biology professor.
  • Imaging of animal cells stained with fluorescent dyes (DAPI and phalloidin) in collaboration with a biology professor.
  • Imaging of microspheres used in tissue substitutes for testing of ultrasound systems (phantoms) with a physics professor.
  • Study of fluorescence emission spectrum of light from carbon black after laser excitation with violet light.
  • Study of spectral response of graphene quantum dots.
  • Imaging of yeast cells cultured on graphene and graphene oxide under various conditions.

Broader Impacts: The system has enabled improved education and outreach:

  • We taught undergraduate students about the history and techniques of optical microscopy and given them and hand-on exposure to the confocal laser scanning microscope in both physics (Optics, Spectroscopy & Microscopy) and biology (Cellular Biology) courses. 
  • We had undergraduate students use the system for their research as part of an NSF Research Experience for Undergraduates (REU) program.
  • We presented a poster (Fig. 2) about the instrument on campus during a faculty and student poster session that was also open to alumni and the off-campus community including remote-controlled operation of the system. Subsequently the poster has been displayed outside of the Laboratory for Advanced Microscopy.
  • We demonstrated the system to high school students from underrepresented communities as part of the university's Science and Engineering Career Exploration Camp.
  • We gave a presentation to elementary school students about optical microscopy during their life sciences unit including a remote-controlled demonstration of the microscope from 50 miles away.
